title: Philip the Arab
text:
Philip the Arab (; 204 – September 249) was <a href="Roman%20emperor">Roman emperor</a> from 244 to 249. He was born in <a href="Hauran">Aurantis</a>, <a href="Arabia%20Petraea">Arabia</a>, in a city situated in modern-day Syria. After the death of <a href="Gordian%20III">Gordian III</a> in February 244, Philip, who had been <a href="Praetorian%20prefect">Praetorian prefect</a>, achieved power. He quickly negotiated peace with the Persian <a href="Sassanid%20Empire">Sassanid Empire</a> and returned to Rome to be confirmed by the senate. During his reign, the city of Rome celebrated its millennium. 
Philip was betrayed and killed at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Verona%20%28249%29">Battle of Verona</a> in September 249 following a rebellion led by his successor, <a href="Decius">Gaius Messius Quintus Decius</a>. Philip's reign of five years was uncommonly stable in a turbulent third century.
During the late 3rd century and into the 4th, it was held by some churchmen that Philip had been the first Christian emperor; he was described as such in <a href="Jerome">Jerome</a>'s "<a href="Chronicon%20%28Jerome%29">Chronicon</a>" ("Chronicle"), which was well known during the Middle Ages, in <a href="Paulus%20Orosius">Orosius</a>' highly popular "Historia Adversus Paganos" ("History Against the Pagans"), and was presented as a Christian in <a href="Eusebius%20of%20Caesarea">Eusebius of Caesarea</a>'s "Historia Ecclesiastica" (<a href="Church%20History%20%28Eusebius%29">Ecclesiastical History</a>). <a href="Philip%20the%20Arab%20and%20Christianity">Modern scholars are divided on the issue.</a>
Early life.
Little is known about Philip's early life and political career. He was born in what is today <a href="Shahba">Shahba</a>, <a href="Syria">Syria</a>, about southeast of <a href="Damascus">Damascus</a>, in <a href="Trachonitis">Trachonitis</a>. His birth city, later renamed Philippopolis, lay within <a href="Hauran">Aurantis</a>, an Arab district which at the time was part of the <a href="Roman%20province">Roman province</a> of <a href="Arabia%20Petraea">Arabia</a>. It is accepted by historians that Philip was indeed an ethnic <a href="Arabs">Arab</a>. He was the son of a local citizen, <a href="Julius%20Marinus">Julius Marinus</a>, possibly of some importance. Allegations from later Roman sources ("<a href="Augustan%20History">Historia Augusta</a>" and "<a href="Epitome%20de%20Caesaribus">Epitome de Caesaribus</a>") that Philip had a very humble origin or even that his father was a leader of brigands are not accepted by modern historians.
While the name of Philip's mother is unknown, he did have a brother, <a href="Gaius%20Julius%20Priscus">Gaius Julius Priscus</a>, an <a href="Equestrian%20class">equestrian</a> and a member of the <a href="Praetorian%20Guard">Praetorian Guard</a> under <a href="Gordian%20III">Gordian III</a> (238–244). In 234, Philip married <a href="Marcia%20Otacilia%20Severa">Marcia Otacilia Severa</a>, daughter of a Roman Governor. They had three children, a son named Marcus Julius Philippus Severus (<a href="Philip%20II%20%28Roman%20emperor%29">Philip II</a>), born in 238, a daughter called Julia Severa or Severina who is known from numismatic evidence but is never mentioned by the ancient Roman sources and a son named Quintus Philippus Severus, born in 247.
The rise to the purple of the <a href="Severan%20dynasty">Severans</a> from nearby <a href="Emesa">Emesa</a> is noted as a motivational factor in Philip's own ascent, due to geographic and ethnic similarity between himself and the <a href="Emesene%20dynasty">Emesan</a> emperors.
Accession to the throne.
Philip's rise to prominence began through the intervention of his brother Priscus, who was an important official under the emperor <a href="Gordian%20III">Gordian III</a>. His big break came in 243, during Gordian III's campaign against <a href="Shapur%20I">Shapur I</a> of Persia, when the <a href="Praetorian%20prefect">Praetorian prefect</a> <a href="Gaius%20Furius%20Sabinius%20Aquila%20Timesitheus">Timesitheus</a> died under unclear circumstances. At the suggestion of his brother Priscus, Philip became the new Praetorian prefect, with the intention that the two brothers would control the young Emperor and rule the Roman world as unofficial regents. Following a <a href="Battle%20of%20Misiche">military defeat</a>, Gordian III died in February 244 under circumstances that are still debated. While some claim that Philip conspired in his murder, other accounts (including one coming from the Persian point of view) state that Gordian died in battle. Whatever the case, Philip assumed the <a href="Tyrian_purple">purple robe</a> following Gordian's death. 
Philip was not willing to repeat the mistakes of previous claimants, and was aware that he had to return to <a href="Rome">Rome</a> in order to secure his position with the <a href="Roman%20senate">senate</a>. However, his first priority was to conclude a peace treaty with Shapur, and withdraw the army from a potentially disastrous situation. Although Philip was accused of abandoning territory, the actual terms of the peace were not as humiliating as they could have been. Philip apparently retained Timesitheus’ reconquest of <a href="Osroene">Osroene</a> and <a href="Roman%20Mesopotamia">Mesopotamia</a>, but he had to agree that <a href="Roman%20Armenia">Armenia</a> lay within Persia's sphere of influence. He also had to pay an enormous indemnity to the Persians of 500,000 denarii. Philip immediately issued coins proclaiming that he had made peace with the Persians ("pax fundata cum Persis").
Leading his army back up the <a href="Euphrates">Euphrates</a>, south of <a href="Circesium">Circesium</a> Philip erected a <a href="cenotaph">cenotaph</a> in honor of Gordian III, but his ashes were sent ahead to <a href="Rome">Rome</a>, where he arranged for Gordian III's deification. Whilst in <a href="Antioch">Antioch</a>, he left his brother Priscus as extraordinary ruler of the Eastern provinces, with the title of "rector Orientis".< Moving westward, he gave his brother-in-law Severianus control of the provinces of <a href="Moesia">Moesia</a> and <a href="Macedonia%20%28Roman%20province%29">Macedonia</a>. He eventually arrived in Rome in the late summer of 244, where he was confirmed <a href="Augustus%20%28honorific%29">"Augustus"</a> Before the end of the year, he nominated his young son "<a href="Caesar%20%28title%29">Caesar</a>" and heir, his wife, <a href="Marcia%20Otacilia%20Severa">Marcia Otacilia Severa</a>, was named Augusta, and he also deified his father Marinus, even though the latter had never been emperor. While in Rome, Philip also claimed an official victory over the Persians with the titles of "Parthicus Adiabenicus", "Persicus Maximus" and "Parthicus Maximus".
Reign.
In an attempt to shore up his regime, Philip put a great deal of effort in maintaining good relations with the Senate, and from the beginning of his reign, he reaffirmed the old Roman virtues and traditions. He quickly ordered an enormous building program in his home town, renaming it <a href="Shahba">Philippopolis</a>, and raising it to civic status, while he populated it with statues of himself and his family. He also introduced the Actia-Dusaria Games in <a href="Bostra">Bostra</a>, capital of Arabia. This festival combined the worship of <a href="Dushara">Dushara</a>, the main Nabataean deity, with commemoration of the <a href="Battle%20of%20Actium">Battle of Actium</a>, as part of the <a href="Roman%20Imperial%20cult">Roman Imperial cult</a>.
The creation of the new city of Philippopolis, piled on top of the massive tribute owed to the Persians, as well as the necessary <a href="donativum">donativum</a> to the army to secure its acceptance of his accession, made Philip desperately short of money. To pay for it, he ruthlessly increased levels of taxation, while at the same time he ceased paying subsidies to the tribes north of the <a href="Danube">Danube</a> that were vital for keeping the peace on the frontiers. Both decisions would have significant impacts upon the empire and his reign.
At the frontiers of the empire.
In 245, Philip was forced to leave Rome as the stability established by Timesitheus was undone by a combination of his death, Gordian's defeat in the east and Philip's decision to cease paying the subsidies. The <a href="Carpi%20%28people%29">Carpi</a> moved through <a href="Dacia">Dacia</a>, crossed the <a href="Danube">Danube</a> and emerged in <a href="Moesia">Moesia</a> where they threatened the <a href="Balkans">Balkans</a>. Establishing his headquarters in <a href="Plovdiv">Philippopolis</a> in <a href="Thracia%20%28Roman%20province%29">Thrace</a>, he pushed the Carpi across the Danube and chased them back into Dacia, so that by the summer of 246, he claimed victory against them, along with the title "Carpicus Maximus". In the meantime, the <a href="Arsacid%20Dynasty%20of%20Armenia">Arsacids of Armenia</a> refused to acknowledge the authority of the Persian king Shapur I, and war with Persia flared up again by 245.
Ludi Saeculares.
Nevertheless, Philip was back in Rome by August 247, where he poured more money into the most momentous event of his reign – the <a href="Ludi%20Saeculares">Ludi Saeculares</a>, which coincided with the one thousandth anniversary of the foundation of Rome. So in April 248 AD (April 1000 <a href="Ab%20urbe%20condita">A.U.C.</a>), Philip had the honor of leading the celebrations of the one thousandth birthday of Rome, which according to tradition was <a href="founding%20of%20Rome">founded</a> on April 21, 753 BC by <a href="Romulus%20and%20Remus">Romulus</a>. Commemorative coins, such as the one illustrated at left, were issued in large numbers and, according to contemporary accounts, the festivities were magnificent and included spectacular games, <a href="Secular%20games">ludi saeculares</a>, and theatrical presentations throughout the city. In the <a href="Colosseum">Colosseum</a>, in what had been originally prepared for Gordian III's planned <a href="Roman%20triumph">Roman triumph</a> over the Persians, more than 1,000 <a href="gladiator">gladiator</a>s were killed along with hundreds of exotic animals including hippos, leopards, lions, giraffes, and one rhinoceros. The events were also celebrated in literature, with several publications, including <a href="Asinius%20Quadratus">Asinius Quadratus</a>' "History of a Thousand Years", specially prepared for the anniversary. At the same time, Philip elevated his son to the rank of co-Augustus.
Downfall.
Despite the festive atmosphere, there were continued problems in the provinces. In late 248, the legions of <a href="Pannonia">Pannonia</a> and Moesia, dissatisfied with the result of the war against the Carpi, rebelled and proclaimed <a href="Pacatianus">Tiberius Claudius Pacatianus</a> emperor. The resulting confusion tempted the <a href="Quadi">Quadi</a> and other <a href="Germanic%20tribes">Germanic tribes</a> to cross the frontier and raid <a href="Pannonia">Pannonia</a>. At the same time, the <a href="Goths">Goths</a> invaded <a href="Moesia">Moesia</a> and Thrace across the <a href="Danube">Danube</a> frontier, and laid siege to <a href="Marcianopolis">Marcianopolis</a>, as the Carpi, encouraged by the Gothic incursions, renewed their assaults in Dacia and Moesia. Meanwhile, in the East, <a href="Jotapianus">Marcus Jotapianus</a> led another uprising in response to the oppressive rule of <a href="Gaius%20Julius%20Priscus">Priscus</a> and the excessive taxation of the Eastern provinces. Two other usurpers, <a href="Silbannacus">Marcus Silbannacus</a> and <a href="Sponsianus">Sponsianus</a>, are reported to have started rebellions without much success.
Overwhelmed by the number of invasions and usurpers, Philip offered to resign, but the Senate decided to throw its support behind the emperor, with a certain <a href="Decius">Gaius Messius Quintus Decius</a> most vocal of all the senators. Philip was so impressed by his support that he dispatched Decius to the region with a special command encompassing all of the Pannonian and Moesian provinces. This had a dual purpose of both quelling the rebellion of Pacatianus as well as dealing with the barbarian incursions.
Although Decius managed to quell the revolt, discontent in the legions was growing. Decius was proclaimed emperor by the Danubian armies in the spring of 249 and immediately marched on Rome. Yet even before he had left the region, the situation for Philip had turned even more sour. Financial difficulties had forced him to debase the <a href="Antoninianus">Antoninianus</a>, as rioting began to occur in Egypt, causing disruptions to Rome's wheat supply and further eroding Philip's support in the capital.
Although Decius tried to come to terms with Philip, Philip's army met the usurper near modern <a href="Verona%2C%20Italy">Verona</a> that summer. Decius easily won the <a href="Battle%20of%20Verona%20%28249%29">battle</a> and Philip was killed sometime in September 249, either in the fighting or assassinated by his own soldiers who were eager to please the new ruler. Philip's eleven-year-old son and heir may have been killed with his father and Priscus disappeared without a trace.
Religious beliefs.
Some later traditions, first mentioned by the historian <a href="Eusebius%20of%20Caesarea">Eusebius</a> in his "<a href="Church%20History%20%28Eusebius%29">Ecclesiastical History</a>", held that Philip was the first <a href="Christianity">Christian</a> Roman Emperor. According to Eusebius ("Ecc. Hist." VI.34), Philip was a Christian, but was not allowed to enter Easter vigil services until he confessed his sins and was ordered to sit among the penitents, which he did willingly. Later versions located this event in <a href="Antioch">Antioch</a>.
However, historians generally identify the later <a href="Constantine%20the%20Great">Emperor Constantine</a>, baptized on his deathbed, as the first Christian emperor, and generally describe Philip's adherence to Christianity as dubious, because non-Christian writers do not mention the fact, and because throughout his reign, Philip to all appearances (coinage, etc.) continued to follow the <a href="Religion%20in%20ancient%20Rome">state religion</a>. Critics ascribe Eusebius' claim as probably due to the tolerance Philip showed towards Christians.
